awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Taxonomic, genetic and functional biodiversity of above-ground bacterial endophytes in subalpine conifers
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrogen (N) is essential to all life on Earth, but only select microbes can reduce or 'fix' N to a form that plants can use. Typically, plants can only use atmospheric N can when fixed by microbes that live in the soil or via a symbiotic relationship with legumes, but recent findings indicate that bacteria inside pine needles can also perform this critical function. In this research, investigators at University of California, Merced will examine the symbiosis between bacteria and limber pine (Pinus flexilis). The goals are to understand the diversity of bacteria present in pine needles, calculate how much N microbes fix and under what conditions, and infer how this fixed N is transferred to the tree. The research could significantly improve our understanding of the N cycle and help identify a currently unknown source of fixed N within coniferous forests. A more complete understanding of the N cycle will also help improve climate models, and a better characterization of the microbes that can fix Nitrogen could lead to advances in crop development. This research will train undergraduates. graduate students and post-doctoral researchers in both field and lab techniques. Additionally, the research will include outreach to teachers, administrators and students at a K-8 STEM school serving under-represented groups, and will develop inquiry-based learning modules in line with Common Core educational standards for incorporation within the K-8 STEM curriculum.

The investigators will examine how the phylogenetic diversity and genetic potential of subalpine tree endophytes affect N fixation within western coniferous forests. Their central hypothesis is that across its broad geographic range, limber pine hosts a broad taxonomic, genetic and functional biodiversity of mutualistic N fixing endophytes, shaped by the local environment, and shared, in part, with neighboring trees. To test this, investigators will examine the biodiversity of endophytes in limber pine and co-occurring species across the limber pine range, identify the factors that structure the patterns of diversity, and determine the relationship between taxonomic diversity and N fixation. Cutting-edge methods in sequencing and genome analysis will be integrated with established and highly sensitive methods for detecting and visualizing N fixing activity in situ to understand how endophyte diversity is shaped by the environment and shapes the N cycle in subalpine forests.

por.por_cntn:
This work was motivated by a long standing question in ecology: Where does the nitrogen (N) come from in temperate and boreal forests? N is a nutrient that is essential to all life, as a key component of DNA, proteins, and chlorophyll.  Although there is plenty of N in the air we breathe, plants can't access that N directly ? only microbes like bacteria and archaea have the enzyme needed to convert N in its gas form to ammonia that plants can use (this process is called nitrogen fixation). In forests dominated by conifers, the known sources of N don't add up and explain the amount of N found in soil and leaves. One reason for that is that these forests don't have a lot of plants like legumes, which house N-fixing bacteria in nodules that typically bring in lots of N to an ecosystem. However, some agricultural plants like rice and sugarcane have bacteria called endophytes inside their leaves that can fix N. The aim of this project was to see if such bacteria are present in conifer needles. We examined the bacterial communities in and on the needles of high elevation conifers across the Western US, and measured the rates of N-fixation in needles. In addition to testing if N-fixation occurs in conifer needles, we wanted to know what factors affect the composition of the bacterial communities associated with needles and the rates at which they fix N. We found that bacteria in conifer needles fix small amounts of N. While the rates were small relative to those in other plants and ecosystems, they could still be important for trees that can live a millennium or more in N-poor soil. We also found that both the rates of N-fixation and the composition of the bacterial communities in conifer needles vary with a number of factors including tree age, tree species, and forest site. Our results suggest that plants that house N fixing bacteria are more common than previously thought, that they are present in natural ecosystems, and that the bacterial communities responsible for N-fixation vary across space and time. Therefore, it helps us understand the N cycle in forests. The project has trained seven people who are first generation college students, women, or from underrepresented minorities, along with two K-12 teachers, and 60 students in grades 3-6. We have worked with teachers to develop curriculum and outreach material on nitrogen fixation, local forest trees, and their associated microbes, and we have taken K-12 students on field trips to study local forest ecosystems.
